column9: 941418: How does multiple OLS regression enhance the understanding of relationships between variables and support causal inference in social science research, considering the concepts discussed in earlier lectures?
column11:
941419: First of all, please read and inspect the dataset.
As mentioned, it contains 2.771 responses from citizens in Copenhagen.
The most frequent highest level of education (Uddannelse) in the data is [edu]
The mean age (alder) in the data is [age]
column13:
941420: Plot the income variable.
The variable is based on a self.reported survey measure of household income. The variable has been made numeric by taking the mid-point of each income interval from the original survey question. If you want to, you can find the original survey here: https://www.kk.dk/sites/default/files/2023-06/Sp%C3%B8rgeskema%202023_0.pdf
If you could, how would you change the categories of the income-question in the survey?
column15:
941421: Calculate a regression model to inspect how income varies between educational-levels. Data is clustered on the Bydel-variable, so use the *clusters*-argument from the lm_robust-function.
Compared to respondents with 1.-10. klasse as their highest level of education, people with Lange videregående uddannelser on average has a household income [LVU]
Compared to respondents with 1.-10. klasse as their highest level of education, people with Gymnasial uddannelse on average has a household income [gym]
column17:
941422: It seems weird that persons with a higher level of education (Gymnasie) earns less than persons with a lower level of education (1. to 10. klasse).
An explanation could be that the age of the person is a confounder: Lenght of educations increase over generations. This means that older respondents on average have shorter educations than younger respondents. On average, grown ups tend to earn more than younger people! So lets see what happens when controlling for age.
When the model is controlled for age...
column19:
941423: So the relationship was not confounded by age... however, age can help explain the relationship between Gymnasieuddannelse and Indkomst in another way - namely as an interaction term.
Calculate an interaction model where Indkomst is explained by Uddannelse, alder, and an interaction term between the two predictors.
Please interpret the interaction and explain how the coeffiecient of Gymnasial uddannelse varies with alder:
column21:
941424: A problem with the model above is that the coefficient for *UddannelseGymnasial uddannelse* (or any of the Uddannelses-coefficients for that matter) is not very informative, as it communicates the uddannelses-coefficientes for age-values of 0 years... therefore, it is always informative to plot interaction models and especially to do so for the values of age actually occuring in the data set!
Use the ?-command to see the documentation from the plot_slopes-function from the marginaleffects-package in r. Now use the plot_slopes-function to visualize the interaction model.
Specify the *variables*-argument to "Uddannelse" and the *condition*-argument to "alder".
Please explain how age and education seems to be interacting when explaining income. Focus on Gymnasial uddannelse, but feel free to broaden the analysis.
column23:
941425: But wait - now we have included age as a first order term in our linear model. This does not have to be the case: As you saw in week 12, the functional form of the relationship between age and immigrant attitudes were better described by a polynomial model.
Now, use what you learned last week to plot the relationship between age and income as a linear model, a model with a quadratic term and a model with a cubic term.
Which of the three functional forms fit the data best?
column25:
941426: Now, calculate a model explaining Indkomst wit alder and a quadratic term of alder.
Interpret the model results:
The coefficient for alder is [alder]
The coefficient for alder^2 is [alder2]
This means, that the effect of age on income is [inter]
column27:
941427: Interpreting polynomial regressions is super hard!
Therefore, it is easier to visualize the results. The model that we just calculated can be used to interpret relationships between the independent and dependent variable - but it can also be used to predict values of the dependent variable based on values on the independent variable.
Use the fucntion "predictions" from the marginaleffects-package on the polynomial model from the question before. This gives as dataset where every row has a predicted income (estimate) based on their age. Now plot age (Alder) and the predicted income (estimate) with a point-plot.
At what age does the positive relationship between age and income seem to turn into a negative one?

column9: Regression er en kontrolleret/matematisk måde at måle sammenhænge ude i den "virkelige verden". Det er en metode hvorpå vi kan isolere interessante variable i vores forskning, og hvordan predictors på forskellige måder kan påvirke outcomes (om x forårsager y). For at finde frem til kausale sammenhænge skal vi sikre et Research Design der er tilfældigt fordelt, da der ellers er selektionsbias.
column13:
Folk har lettere ved at rapportere individindkomst end husholdningsindkomst - reliabilitet. Det er ikke ligeså nemt at rapportere hvor meget din husholdning tjener frem for dig som individ. Fx hvis man er ung og har roomies, så er det dybt forskelligt og individuelt og modsat er der stor forskel på om du er to voksne eller to voksne + 2 børn i en husstand. 

Jeg vil inddele i en kategorisk variabel, med inddelt i lav årlig indkomst, middel indkomst og høj indkomst med intervaller der dækker over en årlig indkomst

column9:
Multiple OLS regression enhance the under between variables by holding other variables constant, the coefficient for predictor is interpreted as its unique association with the outcome. It also does by including important control variables, and thereby reducing the risk of the result being influenced by confounders.

Multiple OLS regression support causal inference because it adjusts for measured confounders. It can also incorporate mediators, moderators and non-linearities, making it possible to test theoretical causal mechanisms.
column13: If I could, I would change the categories, to make them more narrow and avoid the wide intervals, since it forces many households together, that may have a very different income. The categories would also be more evenly spaced, especially in the lower and middle ranges of income, and I would make a category for high income, that is open ended, to avoid having high-income households in arbitrary upper limits (fx. 1.000.000 or more). It could also reflect the local income brackets, by using Danish Statistics income percentiles, making it more comparable.

column21:
For Gymnasial uddannelse, the main effect is strongly negative at age 0, but the positive interaction term indicates that this income gap shrinks steadily as people get older. Younger respondents with gymnasial uddannelse earn substantially less than those with only 1.–10. klasse, but this difference becomes less negative for each additional year of age. As a result, gymnasial respondents catch up as they get older.

A similar pattern appears across several other educational groups. This reflects that younger respondents with higher education are often still studying or early in their careers, while lower-educated respondents may enter the labour market earlier. As age increases, higher-educated groups gradually realize their economic advantage, leading to higher income growth over the lifespan.

Overall the six different models have very much the same trend: You dont make money when you are 0 years old (of course) and they are all positive, meaning you make more money the older you get, no matter the amount of education. Even though the model with Gymnasial uddannelse says when you are 50 you make 0 money? and then it only goes upwards from there. 

For LVU the slope can go further up (until 600000), indicating that people with LVU has the potential to make more money. If you only have highschool you can't make nearly as much, since the y-axis stops at around 200000.

column9: Multiple OLS regression allows researchers to examine the effect of one variable while controlling for others, helping to isolate relationships more clearly. This reduces bias from confounding factors, making it easier to suggest potential causal links. In social science, it provides a clearer, more structured way to understand complex interactions between variables.

column21:
The interaction between age and education shows that the economic value of education unfolds differently across the life course. For Gymnasial uddannelse, the effect on income is strongly negative at young ages, likely because many individuals are still studying, but this negative effect becomes less and less pronounced with age, as shown by the positive and significant interaction term.

Overall, age moderates the impact of education: the income gap between higher and lower educational groups increases over time.

column9: OLS enhances our understanding of correlation and causation between variables by providing statistical models that map associations. We can use these associations to conduct tests to determine how they are (if they are) related and to what extent
